qas.question: Who commented on the nature of time in Book 11 of his confessions?
By what does St. Augustine of Hippo begin to define time?

answers.text: by what it is not rather than what it is

qas.question: What does Augustine call time in Confessions 11.26?

plausible_answers.text: by what it is not rather than what it is

qas.question: How does St. Augustine define memory?
In what book does St. Augustine reflect on how memory works?
What does St. Augustine say when someone asks him about memory?
Where is a similar approach of defining memory also taken?
Who commented on the nature of time in Book 26 of his confessions?

plausible_answers.text: by what it is not rather than what it is

qas.question: By what does St. Augustine of Hippo begin to define memory?
What Does Augustine call memory in Confessions 11.26?
Who calls memory a distention of the mind?
Who ruminates on the nature of approaches?

context: In <b5_0>Book 11 of his Confessions<b5_0/>, <a0_0><b8_0><b12_0>St. Augustine of Hippo<b12_0/><b8_0/><a0_0/> ruminates on the nature of time, asking, "What then is time? If no one asks me, I know: if I wish to explain it to one that asketh, <b6_0>I know not<b6_0/>." He begins to define time <a1_0><b4_0><b9_0>by what it is not rather than what it is<b9_0/><b4_0/><a1_0/>, an approach similar to that taken <b7_0>in other negative definitions<b7_0/>. However, <b11_0>Augustine<b11_0/> ends up calling time <a2_0><b3_0><b10_0>a “distention”<b3_0/> of the mind<b10_0/><a2_0/> (Confessions 11.26) by which we simultaneously grasp the past in memory, the present by attention, and the future by expectation.
